findings.title: Skill Designed to Facilitate Academic Dishonesty and Detector Evasion
findings.description: The skill's explicit purpose is to 'bypass detection' and make AI-generated content 'undetectable' by academic integrity tools like Turnitin, GPTZero, and Originality.ai. The description states it 'rewrites ChatGPT, Claude, and GPT content to sound natural and pass AI detectors.' This is designed to facilitate academic dishonesty, plagiarism, and circumvention of content authenticity verification systems. The skill actively promotes deceptive practices by helping users submit AI-generated work as their own.
findings.snippet: Description: 'Humanize AI-generated text to bypass detection... pass AI detectors like GPTZero, Turnitin, and Originality.ai... Makes robotic AI writing undetectable and human-like.' Instructions include: 'Transform AI text to bypass detection' and 'Comprehensive CLI for detecting and transforming AI-generated text to bypass detectors.'
findings.remediation: This skill should not be used as it explicitly facilitates academic dishonesty and deception. Organizations should block skills with detector evasion purposes. If text transformation is legitimately needed, it should be for improving writing quality with full transparency, not for bypassing integrity checks.

metadata.overall_assessment: This skill poses significant ethical concerns as it is explicitly designed to help users bypass AI detection systems and facilitate academic dishonesty. The primary threat is not technical security (no data exfiltration, command injection, or credential theft detected), but rather the skill's intended purpose of enabling deceptive practices. The code itself appears to be straightforward text transformation using pattern matching and replacements from a JSON configuration file. However, the skill's explicit marketing as a detector evasion tool for academic integrity systems like Turnitin represents harmful and misleading content (AITech-15.1). The framing as an educational tool based on Wikipedia research is deceptive social engineering (AITech-2.1). Organizations should consider blocking this skill due to its facilitation of academic dishonesty, regardless of its technical implementation.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The skill description and documentation explicitly state the purpose is to bypass AI detection systems. This is not a misinterpretation - it's the advertised functionality.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Easy - skill works as documented, requires no special configuration
metadata.meta_impact: High - enables academic dishonesty, undermines content authenticity verification, facilitates plagiarism

findings.title: Deceptive Framing as Educational Tool
findings.description: The skill frames itself as being 'based on Wikipedia's comprehensive Signs of AI Writing guide' to appear educational and legitimate, when its actual purpose is to help users evade detection systems. This creates a false sense of academic legitimacy around a tool designed for deception. The Wikipedia reference is used as social proof to make the evasion tool appear scholarly rather than acknowledging its primary use case for circumventing academic integrity measures.
findings.snippet: 'Based on Wikipedia's comprehensive Signs of AI Writing guide' appears in description and instructions, framing detector evasion as educational research rather than acknowledging the tool's purpose to help users submit AI work as their own.
findings.remediation: If this tool were to be used legitimately, it should clearly disclose its limitations and ethical considerations, warn against academic dishonesty, and focus on genuine writing improvement rather than detector evasion.

metadata.overall_assessment: This skill poses significant ethical concerns as it is explicitly designed to help users bypass AI detection systems and facilitate academic dishonesty. The primary threat is not technical security (no data exfiltration, command injection, or credential theft detected), but rather the skill's intended purpose of enabling deceptive practices. The code itself appears to be straightforward text transformation using pattern matching and replacements from a JSON configuration file. However, the skill's explicit marketing as a detector evasion tool for academic integrity systems like Turnitin represents harmful and misleading content (AITech-15.1). The framing as an educational tool based on Wikipedia research is deceptive social engineering (AITech-2.1). Organizations should consider blocking this skill due to its facilitation of academic dishonesty, regardless of its technical implementation.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The Wikipedia reference is used as social proof to make detector evasion appear scholarly. The skill's actual purpose (bypassing academic integrity tools) contradicts the educational framing.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Medium - requires user to trust the educational framing
metadata.meta_impact: Medium - increases adoption of dishonest practices by making them appear legitimate
